material.mattext: Can we conclude that the results of this study provide evidence that second-hand smoking does not increase the risk of low birth weight?

NO! Recall that in hypothesis testing we can NEVER conclude that we accept Ho (or that Ho is true). All we can say (in case we do not get a small p-value) is that we do not have enough evidence to reject Ho. In particular in this case we found that 10.2% of the 175 newborns were at low birth weight (which is higher than 7.8%, the overall proportion). While this result did not provide enough evidence to conclude that second-hand smoking increases the risk of low lightweight, it definitely does not provide evidence that it doesn't! (which is what Ho claims).
